Interest has grown in the significance of the country-of-origin\ud
impact on the Employment Relations (ER) approaches in the international\ud
subsidiaries of Multinational Companies (MNCs). In this article, a comparative\ud
cross-sectional analysis of German subsidiaries with indigenous UK firms will\ud
be provided. The central issues concern the extent to which German MNCs in\ud
deregulated Anglo-American industrial relations settings draw on the German\ud
ER model, adjust to the host-country context or adopt current ¿best practice¿\ud
prescriptions frequently associated with leading US MNCs. Here, the key\ud
questions are: How and to what extent do different industry-specific forces\ud
interrelate with country-of-origin effects and pressures to adopt ¿best practice¿\ud
approaches to shape subsidiary ER outcomes?</dc:description><dc:description>
